title: Betting companies paid Sh4.7bn tax in 3 years, KRA says
text:
Betting companies paid Sh4.7bn tax in 3 years, KRA says Tuesday February 21 2017 Kenya Revenue Authority Commissioner-General John Njiraini, who told a parliamentary committee that betting firms paid Sh4.7 billion in taxes in three years. PHOTO | DIANA NGILA | NATION MEDIA GROUP In Summary The KRA is of the opinion that raising the tax on gambling could drive the practice underground and lead to illegal gaming. KRA boss John Njiraini said introducing a tax on winnings and raising the levy on betting would be in line with the practice across Africa. Advertisement More by this Author 
Eight betting companies have paid a total Sh4.7 billion in taxes over the past three years, Kenya Revenue Authority (KRA) boss John Njiraini has told the Labour and Social Welfare Committee of the National Assembly. 
In the past two years alone, tax from betting firms has almost tripled from Sh1.2 billion to Sh3.4 billion. 
Mr Njiraini led a team from the KRA to a meeting with the committee to discuss the Betting, Lotteries and Gaming Bill. 
He said the agency is about to start implementing changes to the existing law on gambling. 
He was, however, critical of the law for creating a complex system of taxation that would create opportunities for disputes.
